prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The project consists in a blind CO line search at each target positions by scanning a large part of the accessible frequency range (84-114.5 GHz) in the ALMA band 3. The newly released “frequency scan” observing mode provides automatic setup of the correlator to cover the required 30.5 GHz performing 5 different tunings, appropriately spaced in frequency.
For the observations we require an instantaneous spectral bandwidth of 1875 MHz, corresponding to a spectral resolution of 8 MHz (about 23.5 kms-1) using 16X frequency averaging. The attained velocity resolution is more than suited to probe accurately the line profile of extragalactic CO lines which are expected to have a FWHM between 300-500 kms-1.
The chance of detecting one or more CO lines (or other tracer signals) in band 3 depends on the actual source redshift. Since there are strong indications that the candidate sources have z >= 3, our search should not be limited by the “redshift deserts” located at 0.4 < z < 1 and 1.7 < z < 2.1. Moreover, except for a very marginal portion of the frequency scan, we would be able to detect at least two CO lines starting from the 3-2 transition. Emissions of other tracers could be also detected (such as. CI and H2O) provided that they have sufficient intensity.
As explained in the scientific justification, the target sources of the present proposal are “red peakers” detected in the 250/350/500 um SPIRE/Herschel bands. The extracted fluxes at 500 um ranges between 50 and 80 mJy, they are moderate to bright submillimetre sources, but their actual dust content depends on various unknown parameters, most notably, the distance and the dust physical properties. A number of assumptions had thus to be made to obtain a reasonable prediction of the expected CO peak line intensities.
First, we assumed a dust emissivity of 2.64 kg2 m-1 at 125 um, (Dunne et al. 2003) and a single temperature greybody function of 40K for the target FIR emission. We then estimate a range of dust content by varying the redshifts in the intervals 3 < z < 7, resulting in an estimate of a dust mass in the 8.8 - 10.6 log(M/Msun) range for the whole sample.
Adopting a dust-to-gass mass ratio of 100 and a H2-mass-to-CO luminosity factor of 0.8 (appropriate for SMGs, Solomon Vanden Bout 2005), the above values of Mdust translate in a CO(1-0) line luminosity of 3-7 x 10^11 K km s-1 pc 2, yielding integrated fluxes of 4-6 Jy kms-1, and peak fluxes around 7-10 mJy if one expect a line FWHM of ca. 400 kms-1.
Strictly speaking, these figures refeer to CO(1-0) transition, whereas the target CO lines of the present project will have J > 3. However, according to recent high-z molecular gas detections (e.g., Weiss et al. 2013) the CO ladder of typical SMGs appear to be appreciably populated up to J=6-5 with a rather flat intensity distribution.
Summarising, guided by the above reasonings and keeping ourselves on the safe side, we require a rms sensitivity of 1 mJy, suffificient to allow for a 5 sigma detection of the weaker source candidates.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe a sample of 15 background galaxies detected with the Herschel Space Observatory on behalf the Herschel Virgo Cluster Survey. The galaxy are classified as 'red-peaker' and for this reason they are considered as a strong high redshift candidates. Using the enhanced ALMA capabilities of Cycle 2 we will determine the redshift of these targets and with these data we will put a new constraint on the star formation history of the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
